Image 13 of 30 A crowd of 12,000 showed up to watch the second performance of the 1970 Texas Prison Rodeo at Huntsville Sunday, despite a steady rain that soaked the spectators and made the events doubly hazardous. Above, drivers guide their teams through the muddy arena in one of the more thrilling events, the chuck wagon race. A guard was injured, but not seriously, when a bull penned him against the fence.

Photo: Othell O. Owensby Jr., Houston Chronicle Inmate Jimmy Crosby of Killeen, serving three years at the Ellis... Image 20 of 30 In the "Hard Money Event," inmate James Purlsey gets $50 from between the bull's horns and gets a lift from the bull at the 1972 Texas Prison Rodeo in Huntsville.

Image 23 of 30 From the Oct. 5, 1974, Houston Chronicle: Fans relax in the stands at the opening of the 43rd Texas Prison Rodeo in Huntsville Sunday. They watched events for men and women convicts. Top prize money Sunday was won by Eddie Holland, serving 10 years from San Antonio.
Photo: Bela Ugrin, Houston Chronicle From the Oct. 5, 1974, Houston Chronicle: Fans relax in the stands... Image 24 of 30 From the Oct. 11, 1978, Houston Chronicle: The addition of events for the "Goree Girls," inmates from the nearby women's facility, has given the rodeo an extra dash of colorful fun. This action is from the calf tussle.
Photo: Curtis McGee, Houston Chronicle From the Oct. 11, 1978, Houston Chronicle: The addition of events... Image 25 of 30 From the Oct. 11, 1978, Houston Chronicle: The chosen few. Inmates from all over the TDC system apply and try out for spots in the rodeo, but only a handful make the final cut. Here they await the start of the action.
Photo: Curtis McGee, Houston Chronicle From the Oct. 11, 1978, Houston Chronicle: The chosen few. Inmates... Image 26 of 30 From the Oct. 18, 1981, Houston Chronicle: O'Neal Browning, 52, is seeking to capture the "top hand" award at the annual Texas Prison Rodeo for the seventh time. Wearing regular prison garb except for boots, chaps and hat, Browning is shown in action at the 50th renewal of the event at the state prison in Huntsville. From the Handbook of Texas: Sentenced to life imprisonment for the axe murder of his father, O'Neal Browning gained celebrity on both sides of the bars as the top hand in seven rodeos over three decades.
Photo: Steve Ueckert, Houston Chronicle From the Oct. 18, 1981, Houston Chronicle: O'Neal Browning, 52, is... Image 27 of 30 From the Oct. 11, 1978, Houston Chronicle: Veteran rodeo performer Willie Craig.
Photo: Curtis McGee, Houston Chronicle From the Oct. 11, 1978, Houston Chronicle: Veteran rodeo performer... Image 28 of 30 Landrith Smoot, bull rider, at the Texas Prison Rodeo in Huntsville. October 1986.
Photo: Steve Campbell, Houston Chronicle Landrith Smoot, bull rider, at the Texas Prison Rodeo in... Image 29 of 30 Earl Chaney, from Dallas serving 27 years
Photo: Steve Campbell, Houston Chronicle Earl Chaney, from Dallas serving 27 years Image 30 of 30 48 years ago: Candy Barr performs at Prison Rodeo 1 / 30 Back to Gallery October 1, 1967: On this day, the Houston Chronicle released the top-billing acts for the world-famous Texas Prison Rodeo in Huntsville.
Beginning in 1931, it functioned just like a regular rodeo, scheduled for every Sunday of October, except, inmates would be participating in the traditional contests like calf roping, bull riding and wild cow milking. So long as the prisoners had a clean behavior record for the year, they could participate in the tryouts to make one of 100 possible spots.
Those set to perform during the "outlaw vs. outlaw" tradition included Jo Ann Castle and Norma Zimmer, the "Champagne lady," from the Lawrence Welk Show, Buck Owens and his Buckaroos, and Country Music Hall of Famer, Roy Acuff and his Smoky Mountain Boys.
And, can you imagine the reactions of the inmates, when this veteran prisoner herself was called to the stage? Candy Barr, a former inmate from the Goree unit, turned exotic dancer, was probably the most anticipated opening day performer. After all, she was considered the "first pornographic star." But, that wasn't her only head-turning asset.
In the early '60s, Candy had formed a relationship with Dallas nightclub owner Jack Ruby, who killed Oswald after he allegedly shot President Kennedy. Two months before the President's assassination, Ruby had come to visit Candy. Suspicions as to what Ruby may have told her had the FBI knocking on Candy's door twelve hours after Oswald had been killed.
If a movie was to be made about Candy Barr's colorful life, who do you think would be perfect for the role? Tell us in the comments below, or tweet our host, Michael Callahan, @MCallahanTV using #ForgottenDayHOU.
